Once there was a foolish man who went to someone else's house. The host gave him food, but he complained that it was bland and tasteless. The host heard this and added more salt for him.
After getting the salty taste, he thought to himself:
The reason it tastes good is because of the salt. If a little is already like this, how much more so if there is more?
The foolish man, lacking wisdom, then ate the salt by itself. After eating it, his mouth became parched and he suffered from it.

This is like the non-Buddhists who hear that by fasting one can attain the Way, so they then fast, either for seven days or fifteen days. They only exhaust themselves in hunger, without any benefit to the Way.
It is like that foolish man who, because the salt made it taste good, ate it by itself. This caused his mouth to become parched. This is also like that.

2. The Parable of a Fool Collecting Cow's Milk (2) The Parable of a Fool Collecting Cow's Milk: In the past, there was a fool who was going to hold a banquet for guests and wanted to collect cow's milk to prepare offerings. He thought like this:
If I were to milk the cows every day in advance, the milk would gradually accumulate and there would suddenly be no safe place for it, or it might turn sour.
It would be better to just store it in the cow's belly and wait until the banquet to milk it all at once.
Having thought this, he then tied the mother cow and calf to different places.
After a month, he held the banquet and welcomed the guests. He then led the cows over and wanted to milk them, but the cow's milk was completely dry.
At that time, the guests either became angry or laughed.
The fool is also like this. He wants to practice giving, but says, Wait until I have a lot, and then I will give all at once.
Before they can be collected, they are either taken away by county officials, water, fire, thieves, or they suddenly die without being able to give them in time. It is also like this.

The Parable of Hitting the Head with a Pear (3) The Parable of Hitting the Head with a Pear: In the past, there was a foolish person whose head was hairless. At that time, there was a person who hit his head with a pear, even up to two or three times, all causing injuries. At that time, this foolish person silently endured it and did not know how to avoid it.
The bystanders saw this and said to him:
Why don't you avoid it and stay to be hit until your head is broken?
The foolish person replied:
That person is arrogant, relying on his strength, foolish and lacking wisdom. Seeing that my head is hairless, he thinks it is a stone and hits my head with a pear until it is broken like this.
The bystanders said:
You yourself are foolish and ignorant. How can you call him foolish?
If you are not foolish, why don't you run away when beaten, even to the point of a broken head?

The bhiká¹£u is also like this. He is unable to fully cultivate faith, precepts, learning, and wisdom, but only maintains dignified conduct to attract offerings, like that foolish person who is beaten by others but does not know to avoid them, even to the point of injury, and instead calls the other person foolish. This bhiká¹£u is also like this.
The Parable of the Wife Pretending to Be Dead (4) The Parable of the Wife Pretending to Be Dead: In the past there was a foolish man whose wife was upright and beautiful, and he loved her very much.

The wife had no sincerity or faith. Later, in the middle of things, she associated with others, and her licentious desires grew. She wanted to abandon her own husband and follow her paramour. She then secretly told an old woman,
After I leave, you should bring a dead woman's corpse and place it in the house, and tell my husband that I have already died.
The old woman later waited until her husband was not at home, and placed a dead corpse in his house.
When her husband returned, the old woman said:
Your wife has died.
The husband went to see for himself, and it was indeed his wife. He wailed and lamented, piled up firewood and oil, burned her body, and carried the ashes in a bag day and night.
Later, the wife grew tired of her paramour and returned home. She said to her husband:
I am your wife.
The husband replied:
My wife has been dead for a long time. Who are you, falsely claiming to be my wife?
Even after two or three times, he still did not believe her.

Just like the non-Buddhists who, upon hearing the wrong teachings of others, become confused and attached, considering them to be true and never to be changed. Even if they hear the correct teachings, they do not believe or accept them.

5. The Parable of Seeing Water When Thirsty (5) In the past, there was a person who was foolish and lacked wisdom. He was extremely thirsty and needed water. Seeing the heat haze, he took it to be water. He then ran after it to the Ganges River. When he arrived at the river, he looked at it but did not drink.
The people around him said:
You are suffering from thirst and ran after the water. Now that you have reached the water, why don't you drink?
The foolish person replied:
You can drink it all, and then I will drink it. This water is extremely much and cannot be exhausted all at once, so I will not drink it.
At that time, when the people heard these words, they all laughed loudly.

It is like the non-Buddhists who take the principles in a biased way. Because they are unable to fully uphold the Buddha's precepts, they then do not accept them, causing them to have no chance of attaining the Way in the future and to transmigrate in the cycle of birth and death. It is also like that foolish person who sees the water but does not drink, being laughed at by the times.
6. The Parable of the Dead Son (6) Once there was a foolish man who raised seven sons. One son died first.
When this foolish man saw that his son had died, he wanted to leave him in the house and go away himself.
A bystander saw this and said to him:
Life and death are different paths. You should quickly prepare and take him far away to bury him. How can you leave him and go away yourself?
At that time, the foolish man, having heard these words, immediately thought to himself:
If I cannot leave him and must bury him, then I need to kill another son and carry them on both shoulders in order to be able to take them away.
So he immediately killed another son and carried them away to bury them in the deep forest.
When people saw this, they deeply laughed in derision, thinking it unprecedented.
It is like a bhiká¹£u who privately violates a single precept, feeling reluctant to repent and remaining silent, concealing it and claiming to be pure. If someone knows and tells him:
One who has left the household life should uphold the precepts like guarding a bright pearl, not allowing them to be incomplete. How can you now violate the precepts you have received and not repent?
The one who has violated the precepts says:
If I must repent, I will then violate them again and only then come out.
He then breaks the precepts, creates much unwholesomeness, and only then comes out all at once.
Like that foolish person who, after one child has died, kills another child. Now this bhiká¹£u is also like this.

The Parable of Mistaking Someone for an Elder Brother (7) The Parable of Mistaking Someone for an Elder Brother: In the past there was a man who was handsome, wise, and had much wealth. Everyone in the world who heard of him praised him.
At that time there was a foolish person who saw him like this and said, You are my elder brother.
The reason is this: when he had money and wealth, those in need would use it, so he was called elder brother;
when he saw them repaying the debt, he said he was not their elder brother.
Bystanders said to him:
You are a foolish person!
How can you call someone your elder brother when you need their money?
And when it comes to repaying the debt, you say he is not your elder brother.
The foolish man replied:
I recognized him as my elder brother because I wanted to get his money and wealth. He is not really my elder brother. When it comes to repaying the debt, I call him not my elder brother.
People who heard this could not help but laugh at him.

It is just like those non-Buddhists who, hearing the Buddha's good words, greedily steal them and make them their own. Even when bystanders teach them to practice, they are unwilling to practice and say:
For the sake of profit, I take the Buddha's words to transform and guide sentient beings, but there is no real matter. How can I practice?
It is like a fool who says, This is my elder brother in order to obtain wealth, but when it comes to repaying debts, he says, He is not my brother. This is also like that.

The Parable of the Mountain Barbarians Stealing the Official Treasury (8) The Parable of the Mountain Barbarians Stealing the Official Treasury: In the past, there was a mountain barbarian who stole the king's treasury and fled far away.
At that time, the king sent people to search in the four directions, captured him, and brought him before the king.
The king then accused him of the clothes he obtained. The mountain barbarian replied:
These clothes of mine are the possessions of my ancestors.

The king had him put on the clothes. Since they were not originally owned by the mountain barbarian, he did not know how to wear them. What should have been on the hands was put on the feet, and what should have been on the waist was worn on the head instead.
When the king saw the thief, he gathered the ministers and discussed this matter together, saying:
If these are the clothes that have been passed down from your ancestors, you should know how to wear them. Why are you wearing the upper as lower?
Because you do not understand, I know for certain that your clothes must have been stolen, not your old possessions.

Using this as a metaphor, the king is like the Buddha, the treasure trove is like the Dharma. The foolish Qiang people are like the non-Buddhists. They secretly listen to the Buddha's teachings and take them as their own, but because they do not understand, they arrange the Buddha's teachings in disarray, not knowing the characteristics of the Dharma.
It is like the mountain Qiang people who obtained the king's precious clothes, not knowing the sequence, they put them on in disarray, it is also like this.
The Parable of Praising the Father's Virtues (9) The Parable of Praising the Father's Virtues: In the past, there was a person who praised his father's virtues among the people, saying:
My father is kind and benevolent, not harming or stealing, speaking truthfully and practicing generosity.
At that time, there was a foolish person who heard these words and thought:
My father's virtues and practices surpass yours.
The people asked:
What virtues and practices are there? Please tell us about them.
The fool replied:
My father has abstained from sexual desire since childhood and has never been defiled.
The people said:
If he abstains from sexual desire, how did you come to be born?
He was deeply ridiculed by the people of the time.

It is like the ignorant people in the world who want to praise a person's virtues but do not know the truth, and end up slandering them, just like that fool who intended to praise his father but ended up saying something wrong. This is also like that.

The third floor house parable (10) In the past, there was a rich fool who was ignorant and unknowledgeable. He went to another rich person's house and saw a three-story building that was tall, spacious, and beautifully decorated, with an open and airy loft. He became envious and thought:
My wealth is no less than his, so why haven't I built such a building?
He then called a carpenter and asked:
Can you build a house as nice as that one?
The carpenter replied:
It is my work.
He then said:
Now you can build a tower for me like that.
At that time, the carpenter immediately laid out the ground and built a tower with bricks.
The foolish man, seeing him build a house with bricks, still had doubts and could not understand. He asked:
What do you want to build?
The carpenter replied:
A three-story house.
The foolish man said again:
I don't want the two lower stories of the house. You can first build the uppermost story for me.
The carpenter replied:
That is impossible. How can one build the second story without building the lowest story?
Without building the second story, how can one build the third story?
The foolish man insisted:
I don't need the two lower stories now. You must build the uppermost one for me.
When people heard this, they became strange and laughed, all saying:
How is it possible that one who does not build the lowest first house can get to the highest?
It is like the four types of disciples of the World-Honored One, who are unable to diligently cultivate and respect the Three Jewels, are lazy and indolent, yet seek the fruits of the path, saying:
I now do not need the other three lower fruits, I only seek to attain the fruit of arhatship.
They are also ridiculed by the people of the time, no different from that foolish person.

The Parable of the Brahmin Killing His Son (11) The Parable of the Brahmin Killing His Son: In the past, there was a Brahmin who considered himself very knowledgeable, and was not unclear about various star techniques and skills, relying on himself like this, wanting to show his virtue, and finally went to another country, holding his child and crying.
Someone asked the Brahmin:
Why are you crying?
The Brahmin said:
This child will die in seven days. I am crying out of pity for his untimely death.
At that time, people said to him:
Human life is difficult to know. Calculations are often mistaken. Even if he does not die after seven days, why cry in advance?
The brahmin said:
The sun and moon can be darkened, the stars can fall, but what I have recorded will never be violated.
For the sake of fame and profit, on the seventh day he killed his own son to prove his words.
At that time, the people of the world heard that his child had died after seven days, and all exclaimed:
He is truly wise. What he said was not wrong.
With faith in their hearts, they all came to pay their respects.

It is like the four kinds of disciples of the Buddha who, for the sake of profit, claim to have attained the Way. There is a foolish method of killing good men and falsely displaying compassionate virtue, causing one to receive suffering endlessly in the future, like the brahmin who killed his son to deceive the world in order to verify his words.

12. The Parable of Boiling Black Honey Syrup (12) The Parable of Boiling Black Honey Syrup: In the past, there was a foolish person who was boiling black honey syrup. A wealthy person came to his house.
At that time, this foolish person thought like this:
I will now take black honey syrup and give it to this wealthy person.
He then put in a little water and placed it over the fire.
Then, he fanned it on top of the fire, hoping to make it cool.
A person beside him said:
If you don't put out the fire below and keep fanning it, how can it become cool?
At that time, all the people laughed at him.

It is just like the non-Buddhists who do not extinguish the blazing fire of afflictions, performing a little ascetic practice, lying on thorns, and scorching themselves with the five heats, hoping for the path of coolness and tranquility. It will never happen. In vain, they are ridiculed by the wise, and the suffering they experience now will bring calamity for future eons.

13. The Parable of a Man Who Likes to Get Angry (13) The Parable of a Man Who Likes to Get Angry In the past, there was a man who was sitting in a house with many people, praising the virtues of an outsider, saying: He only has two faults:
First, he likes to get angry, second, he acts hastily.

At that time, this man was outside the door, and upon hearing these words, he became angry. He immediately entered the house, grabbed the foolish and evil person who had spoken about him, and beat him with his hands.
The people beside him asked:
Why did you hit him?
That man replied:
When have I ever liked to get angry or acted hastily?
Yet this person said:
'I like to get angry and act hastily.'
That's why I hit him.
The people beside him said:
The signs of your current liking to get angry and act hastily are immediately evident. Why do you deny it?
When others speak of his faults and blame him, he is deeply ridiculed by the crowd for his foolishness and confusion.

It is like a man in the world who indulges in drinking, becomes intoxicated and negligent, and when seen by others being scolded, he in turn gives rise to resentment and anger. If this foolish man avoids hearing about his own faults and sees others speaking about him, he wants to beat them in return.

The Parable of Killing the Caravan Leader to Sacrifice to the Gods (14) The Parable of Killing the Caravan Leader to Sacrifice to the Gods: In the past, there was a merchant who wanted to enter the great ocean. The method for entering the great ocean was to have a guide and then set out. He then went together to seek and found a guide. Having found him, they set out together and arrived in a vast wilderness.
There was a heavenly shrine that required a human sacrifice in order to pass through. Then the merchants all thought together and said:
All of our companions are our relatives, so how can we kill them?
Only this guide can be used to sacrifice to the gods.
They then killed the guide and used him as a sacrifice.
After worshipping heaven, they lost their way and did not know where to go. They died of exhaustion.
All worldly people are also like this. If they want to enter the ocean of Dharma to obtain its treasures, they should cultivate good dharmas and take them as their guide.

If they destroy good conduct, they will be on the long road of birth and death forever without a way out, experiencing the three paths of suffering for a long time, just like those merchants who are about to enter the ocean, killing their guide, losing their way, and eventually dying of exhaustion.

The Parable of the Doctor Giving the Princess Medicine to Make Her Grow Up Quickly (15) The Parable of the Doctor Giving the Princess Medicine to Make Her Grow Up Quickly: In the past there was a king who gave birth to a daughter. He called a doctor and said:
Give her medicine to make her grow up quickly.
The doctor replied:
I have good medicine that can make her grow up quickly, but I don't have it now. I need to go find it.
By the time I get the medicine, the king must not look at her. After I give her the medicine, then I will show her to the king.

He then went far away to get medicine for twelve years, obtained the medicine and returned to give it to the girl to take. He took her to see the king, and when the king saw her he was delighted and thought to himself:
He is truly a good doctor, who can give my daughter medicine to make her grow up quickly.
He then ordered his attendants to bestow precious treasures on him.
At that time, the people laughed at the king's lack of wisdom, not understanding how to calculate the years since her birth, and seeing her grown up, they considered it the power of the medicine.
People in the world are also like this. They go to a good teacher and say:
I want to seek the Way. I wish to be taught to make me attain it quickly.

The good teacher uses skillful means to teach them to sit in meditation and contemplate the twelve links of dependent origination, gradually accumulating various virtues and attaining arhatship. They are overjoyed and say:
Excellent! Great teacher!
You can quickly enable me to realize the most wonderful Dharma.
16. The Parable of Watering Sugarcane (16) The Parable of Watering Sugarcane: In the past, two people planted sugarcane together and made a vow:
Whoever grows better sugarcane will be rewarded, and whoever grows worse will be heavily punished.
At that time, one of the two people thought:
Sugarcane is extremely sweet. If we extract the juice and water the sugarcane trees with it, they will surely become sweeter and I will win.
He then pressed the sugarcane to extract the juice and used it to water the sugarcane, hoping for a better taste, but it ruined the seeds instead. All the sugarcane was lost.

People in the world are also like this. They want to seek good blessings, but relying on their own wealth and power, they use their influence to oppress the people below and plunder their wealth, using it as the basis for creating blessings and expecting good results. They do not know that in the future they will instead bring disaster upon themselves, just like pressing sugarcane and losing both the juice and the plant.

17. The Parable of the Half Penny (17) The Parable of the Half Penny: In the past, a merchant borrowed half a penny from someone and was unable to repay it for a long time, so he went to repay the debt.

In front of him was a great river, which he hired to cross for two pennies, and then he reached the other side to repay the debt, but he did not see the debtor. He returned to cross the river and hired two pennies again.
For the sake of a half penny debt, he lost four pennies, and he was also exhausted from the road, with very little to be borrowed and much to be lost, and in the end he was ridiculed by the crowd.

People in the world are also like this. They want little fame and profit, but it ruins their great practice. They only care about themselves and do not consider propriety and righteousness. They currently receive a bad reputation and later attain painful retribution.

The Parable of Grinding a Knife on a Building (18) The Parable of Grinding a Knife on a Building: In the past, there was a poor and destitute man who worked for the king for many days and months, and his body became emaciated.
The king saw him with pity and gave him a dead camel.

The poor man, having obtained it, immediately skinned himself, and because he disliked the dullness of the knife, he sought a stone to grind it. He then obtained a grinding stone on the roof of a building, ground the knife to sharpness, came down, and skinned himself.

In this way, he repeatedly went up and down to grind the knife, and later, exhausted and reluctant, unable to go up frequently, he hung the camel on the roof, went to the stone to grind the knife, and was deeply ridiculed by the people.

It is like a foolish person who destroys the precepts and takes much money and wealth to cultivate merit, hoping to be reborn in the heavens, like hanging a camel on the roof to grind a knife, using much effort and obtaining very little.

The Parable of Losing a Spoon While on a Boat (19) The Parable of Losing a Spoon While on a Boat: In the past, a person was crossing the ocean by boat and lost a silver spoon, which fell into the water. He immediately thought:
I will now draw a mark on the water, leave it behind, and later I will retrieve it.
After two months of travel, he arrived at the countries of lions and saw a river. He immediately entered it to search for the spoon he had originally lost.
The people asked:
What do you want to do?
He replied:
I have lost a ladle and now want to find it.
They asked:
Where did you lose it?
He answered:
I lost it when I first entered the ocean.
They further asked:
How long has it been lost?
He said:
It has been lost for two months.
They asked:
If it has been lost for two months, why are you looking for it here?
He replied:
When I lost the ladle, I drew a mark on the water. The water I drew then is no different from this. That is why I am looking for it here.
They further asked:
Although the water is the same, you lost it there in the past. Why are you looking for it here now? How can you find it?
At that time, the people all laughed loudly.
It is also like non-Buddhists who do not practice correctly, mistakenly taking suffering as good and seeking liberation, just like a fool who loses a treasure here but seeks it there.
The Parable of the People Saying the King is Indulgent and Violent (20) The Parable of the People Saying the King is Indulgent and Violent: In the past, a person criticized the king's faults, saying:
The king is extremely violent and unreasonable in governing.

The king heard these words and became greatly angry. Without investigating who said this, he trusted the flatterers and caught a virtuous minister, ordering him to flog his back and take a hundred ounces of flesh.

Someone testified that this was not his words, and the king's mind then regretted it. He took a thousand ounces of flesh to use as a supplement for his back. During the night, he groaned in great pain.
The king heard his voice and asked:
Why are you suffering?
I took a hundred ounces from you and gave you ten times that, is that not enough?
Why are you suffering?
The bystanders replied:
Great King!
It's like cutting off a child's head. Even if one gets a thousand heads, one still can't avoid the child dying. Even if one gets ten times more meat, one still can't avoid the pain.

The foolish person is also like this. Not fearing the afterlife, they greedily crave present pleasures and harshly oppress sentient beings, stirring up the common people and obtaining much wealth, hoping to extinguish their offenses and obtain blessings in return.
It's like that king cutting open people's backs and taking their flesh, using other flesh to cover it up, hoping it won't hurt. There is no such possibility.

The Parable of a Woman Desiring Another Child (21) The Parable of a Woman Desiring Another Child: In a past life, there was a woman who had just had one child and wanted another. She asked other women:
Who can make me have another child?
An old woman said to the woman:
I can make you have another child as you wish, but you must make offerings to the gods.
She asked the old woman:
What is needed for the offerings?
The old woman said:
Kill your son, take his blood to sacrifice to the gods, and you will surely have many sons.
At that time, this woman then followed his words and wanted to kill her son.
Beside her, a wise person sneered and scolded:
Foolish and ignorant, to the point of doing this.
Can one obtain what has not yet been born?
And kill the present child.

The foolish person is also like this, seeking to create happiness for what has not yet been born, throwing themselves into a fire pit, and harming their body in various ways to attain rebirth in the heavens.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Sutra of a Hundred Parables, Scroll 1 Thus have I heard:
Once the Buddha was in Rajagriha, in the Bamboo Grove of Crow Fort, together with many great bhikshus, bodhisattva-mahasattvas, and the eight groups of beings, thirty-six thousand in all.

At that time, in the assembly there were five hundred non-Buddhist Brahmins who rose from their seats and said to the Buddha, We have heard that the Buddha's Way is vast and deep, and none can reach it. We have come to ask about it. We only wish that you will explain it.
The Buddha said,
Very good.
He asked:
Does the world exist or not?
He replied:
It both exists and does not exist.
The brahman said:
If it exists now, how can you say it does not exist?
If it does not exist now, how can you say it exists?
He replied:
The living are said to exist, the dead are said not to exist, so it is said to be both existent and nonexistent.
He asked:
From what are people born?
He replied:
People are born from grains.
He asked:
From what are the five grains born?
He replied:
The five grains are born from the four great elements, fire, wind, and so forth.
He asked:
From what are the four great elements, fire, wind, and so forth, born?
He replied:
The four great elements, fire, wind, and so forth, are born from space.
He asked:
From what is space born?
He replied:
It is born from the nonexistent.
He asked:ğŸ”½What is the nonexistent?
Non-existence arises from what?
He replied:
It arises from spontaneity.
He asked:
Spontaneity arises from what?
He replied:
It arises from nirvana.
He asked:
Nirvana arises from what?
The Buddha said:
Why is the matter you are asking about so profound?
Nirvana is the Dharma of non-birth and non-death.
He asked:
Has the Buddha entered nirvana yet?
He replied:
I have not yet entered nirvana.
If you have not entered nirvana, how can you know that nirvana is eternally blissful?
The Buddha said:
I will now ask you, are all sentient beings in the world suffering or blissful?
He replied:
Sentient beings are extremely suffering.
The Buddha said:
What is called suffering?
He replied:
I see that when sentient beings die, the pain is difficult to endure, so I know that death is suffering.
The Buddha said:
You are now not dead, but you also know the suffering of death. I see that the Buddhas of the ten directions are not born and do not die, so I know nirvana is eternally blissful.
The five hundred Brahmins' minds opened up and their thoughts were resolved. They sought to receive the five precepts, realized the fruit of stream-entry, and sat as before.
The Buddha said:
You should listen well!
I will now explain many analogies for you in detail.
